body:
>     * either API Guardian should be osgi-ified and it should be imported by bundles that use it (can be an optional import as the bundle will run without it),

That sounds reasonable.

>     * we should consider changing the retention of `@API` to `CLASS`.

The `@API` annotation is supported for runtime access via the Java reflection APIs. Thus changing the retention from `RUNTIME` to `CLASS` is not an option in my opinion.

> The `@API` annotation is supported for runtime access via the Java reflection APIs. Thus changing the retention from `RUNTIME` to `CLASS` is not an option in my opinion.

If that is an anticipated use case, then we should definitely OSGi-ify the API Guardian jar and change the JUnit 5 bundles to optionally import the packages, otherwise the annotations won't be available for reflection for code running inside an OSGi framework.

issue.title: Add OSGi metadata

repository.name: apiguardian
repository.description: Java annotation for documenting the @API status of types and members in Java APIs. Maintained by the JUnit team.

issue.body:
From discussion in https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2547, it was noted that the `@API` annotation of API guardian has `RUNTIME` retention policy - which means that some code might reasonably expect it to be available at runtime. (This is in contrast to a comment made earlier [here](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/pull/1353#issuecomment-377794249) stating that it was a compile-only dependency.)

Given that runtime retention implies that runtime usage is anticipated, API Guardian should probably at some stage get its own OSGi metadata to make it available at runtime in an OSGi context.

body: Raised https://github.com/apiguardian-team/apiguardian/issues/22 to deal with the API-guardian side of this. Can't progress this issue until there is a version of API Guardian publically available with OSGi metadata.

> Raised apiguardian-team/apiguardian#22 to deal with the API-guardian side of this.

A PR has now been raised for this: apiguardian-team/apiguardian#23

> Can't progress this issue until there is a version of API Guardian publically available with OSGi metadata.

Actually, I realised that this is not true - we could modify the current JUnit 5 bundles so that they *optionally* import API Guardian and it won't matter that there is no publicly available bundle yet. That would close off this issue without needing to wait for the next API Guardian release. (And in fact, I realised that there is a public OSGi version of API Guardian available in the Eclipse repositories that form part of the Eclipse distribution - I used a different BSN to make sure that we don't clash.)

issue.title: Optionally import org.apiguardian.api in OSGi metadata

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Fixes #2547.

A "regression" in the context of this issue (compared with the current situation) would be if importing API Guardian suddenly became required, as that would break existing systems. To guard against such a regression, I modified the `verifyOSGi` task so that it excludes the API Guardian jar/bundle from consideration by the resolver. Thus the test will prove that API Guardian is not required for resolving JUnit 5 bundles.

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the [JUnit Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/002a0052926ddee57cf90580fa49bc37e5a72427/CONTRIBUTING.md#junit-contributor-license-agreement).

---

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] Method [preconditions](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org.junit.platform.commons/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [x] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [x] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)
- [x] All [continuous integration builds](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5#continuous-integration-builds) pass

body:
> I used a different BSN to make sure that we don't clash

What's a BSN?

> What's a BSN?

Bundle Symbolic Name

See... I still remember something from my OSGi days. ðŸ˜‰

Yes, a BSN is an identifier that (together with the bundle version) uniquely identifies a bundle. If you have two different bundles with the same BSN, it can cause issues. The Eclipse bundle's BSN is `org.apiguardian` whereas this PR's is `org.apiguardian.api` (which is the same as the bundle's module name).

> My question: if API guardian is not intended to be a runtime dependency, then why is it defined with `RUNTIME` retention?

We used to have it as a `compileOnly` dependency but that led to downstream projects, i.e. projects containing tests that used Jupiter annotations, to get compiler warnings because the `API.Status` enum was missing. We could switch that to `compileApiOnly` so at least Gradle projects wouldn't have it on their test runtime classpath.
**Team decision:** Let's add OSGi metadata to API Guardian and optionally import it in JUnit, as you've proposed.

rename.to: API Guardian should be optionally imported in OSGi metadata

body: @kriegfrj Now that https://github.com/apiguardian-team/apiguardian/pull/23 is merged can we update to 1.1.2-SNAPSHOT and simplify our setup?

Yes! If I had thought of it I would have held off and done that from the start, rather than waste time and effort figuring out how to add the right version imports for the non-OSGi jar! At least I learned something about Gradle! ðŸ˜„
